heading: the onion of the airwaves
subheading: the irreverent newspaper that became a web site and published its first book in april will soon be a radio show.
author: wired news report
text: just when you think the onion can't get any wackier or funnier, it moves to another plane.the newspaper led to a web site, which begat a book, and now the wisconsin-based satirical newspaper and web site have spawned a radio show.the onion radio news will debut on stations nationwide as a series of short comedy vignettes starting 1 september. the show will air weekdays as two different 30-second features taken from the newspaper and web site. it will be broadcast at different times on different stations between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. on the westwood one radio network.see also: the onion hits the big time- - - - - -"the onion radio news will be a lot like the print and online versions of the onion, but without all that annoying reading," editor in chief scott dikkers said in a statement.a westwood one spokeswoman could not be reached for comment. the network produces programming for 5,000 radio stations, including shows featuring don imus, g. gordon liddy, larry king, charles osgood, dan rather, david letterman, and martha stewart.the announcement follows the release of the onion book, our dumb century: 100 years of headlines from america's finest news source. the crown publication sold out its press run of 85,000 when it was released on april fool's day and quickly jumped to the top of the new york times bestseller list. nbc is preparing a tv special based on the book that is scheduled to air during the fall ratings sweeps period.it will be interesting to see how the onion translates stories such as "should the us impose limits on incredibly stupid shit?" which was the 23 june lead story, for radio. the web site bears a disclaimer in small print stating that "the onion is not intended for readers under 18 years of age."the onion began as a print paper in 1988 and launched online in 1996. it boasts 500,000 web visitors and 400,000 print readers every week.
